reviews.comment_teaching:
*** Prof. Yongchang ZHU***

" How to test whether one knows Analysis? The answer is to test whether he knows Fourier Analysis.
How to test whether one knows Algebras? The answer is to test whether he knows Tensor Product."___ Prof. ZHU

Prof. ZHU is an extremely non-trivial human, he scored highest in all aspects of his PhD qualification exams in Yale (if I remembered correctly :0). Also, Prof. Ivan IP, whose supervisor was Prof. ZHU in UG, is an extremely non-trivial neko that gave tons of happiness to year 1 students this semester. It is clear to see how non-trivial Prof. ZHU is so let's denote Prof. ZHU by non-trivial human. (just kidding :P)

Non-trivial human's teaching pace increases exponentially with time. This is my feeling about 3131:

Group Theory: This is an Algebra course for Babies ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡° )
Ring Theory: This is a standard undergraduate Algebra course (≖͞_≖̥)
Module Theory: Any % speedrun 5111 (இωஇ)

Roughly speaking, the teaching style of non-trivial human is between FF and Ivan. Non-trivial human has a gradual teaching pace with motivations and examples so you can catch up with the lectures easily. Also, non-trivial human likes to give proof sketches and let us fill in the details after class. One thing that I am impressed by non-trivial human is that his teaching notes is basically some important lemmas and theorems without proof while he can present the ideas and proofs in an organized way throughout this course...extremely non-trivial Orz.

In class, non-trivial human like to interact with students (but most of us were shy anyway (///ω///)). One of my unforgettable memories in class is that somehow non-trivial human didn't know how to prove Chinese Remainder Theorem, and he just picks somebody to present the proof in front of the whole class, and that guy is me =͟͟͞͞(꒪ᗜ꒪ ‧̣̥̇) 劇烈害怕.jpg. Perhaps the most effective way to check whether you understand the proof is to present the proof in front of non-trivial human. (✘_✘)


*** Our TA, Jeff York YE ***

We have the same TA as 2043, 3043. If you don't know how non-trivial he is, let me show you a dialogue in class before introducing this TA :)

ZHU: "If you wish to continue the PhD study, then you should be better than the best student in 5000-level courses"
Me: "Jeff?"
(Whole class Laugh)
ZHU: "No, better than Jeff is IMPOSSIBLE​! Jeff is the best student in recent 10 years, or probably 20 years..."

Same as the 2043, 3043 review, I have to emphasize that he is an extremely non-trivial GENIUS. Personally, Jeff's 3131 tutorial problems are easier than that of 2043 and 3043 because you can at least understand what's the problem asking for before attending his tutorials (✘_✘)??? Tutorial problems are still very difficult and some problems are related to other fields like Algebraic Geometry and Algebraic Number Theory. I think it is good to give you a taste of other fields that are related to algebra so that you won't suffer from Ivan IP's UROP/ SCIE like me after knowing how disgusting algebra is (-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩_-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩).

There are some easier problems in Jeff's tutorials that you should be able to finish it after revision. And I also encourage you to read the solution of some advanced problems cuz some of them are classical and you will see them in 5111 for sure :D. If you can understand the solution to tutorial problems and master the idea of each proof, I am pretty sure, or 120% sure that this course will be an easy A for you.

Btw, Jeff is the most effective TA that I have ever seen. He usually grades our homework within 1 day and he graded our paper within 1.5 hours after the final exam (surprise!!! Σ(ŎдŎ|||)ﾉﾉ).

reviews.comment_workload:
We have a total of 7 Homework through this course but only 5~6 problems in total are difficult. Homework doesn't contribute to my workload pretty much in the course. The major workload is reading proofs shown in lectures. It is extremely important to master and memorize those proofs cuz I think that the tricks for solving Algebras problems are similar sometimes.

Also I spent time in construct examples and counter-examples. eg:
      - Find Group G and Subgroup N, M s.t. N ◃M ◃G but N ◃G
      - Find a subgroup of G×G s.t. it cannot be written as N×M where N, M are subgroups of G
      - Give an example of E.D. but not field, P.I.D. but not E.D., U.F.D. but not P.I.D., ...etc.
It is crucial to construct examples yourself in an algebra course since solving algebra problems is highly rely on your instinct and past experience personally. It is quite important to build up a sense for algebra by consistent practice.

good luck :)

reviews.author: overloadtension
reviews.title: interesting, must take/audit
reviews.comment_content:
There is noticeable difference from the proposal to what is actually covered, which can be seen from the attachments.
The syllabus is quite different compared to other reviews. However I think this is quite a popular path for abstract algebra courses among universities according to my experience of searching answers online

Given enough time to learn this course, one may find beauty behind these abstract structures and appreciate the applications to seeming irrelevant problems. Of course, it would be a torture if one have to learn them in a rush.

Professor follows the book contents closely so self-studying the contents should be ok. However, Artin's book is dense and not too easy to understand as pointed out in other reviews. I finally understand the contents by slowing down my pace and re-reading the contents. Trying to work out the given proofs by myself turns out to be helpful.

P.S. Actually I am quite fond of this book. I like the tone and clear explanation of the motivation behind the mathematical results.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor would write down the notes in tablet in each lecture. The theorems and examples are mostly similar to the ones appearing in text book. The notes seems to be clear enough.
However, I can't tell further since I do not attend lecture often as I lag behind the contents most of the time. I also use the text book for major reference instead of notes.
The attendance rate for lectures is quite low, often 5-8 people out of 21 students (for lecture I attended)

For tutorials, the attendance rate is even lower even the timeslot is just after one of the 2 weekly lectures. From the GitHub page that the TA distributes tutorial notes, it seems that tutorial is not held after 22 March...
reviews.comment_grading:
HW(30%): 3 hw, to be elaborated in workload section
Final exam(70%): 1.5 hour, open-book/notes, 13 T/F questions + 8 short questions

The difficulty of the questions are reasonable as it is expected to solve them in 10 minutes and the solutions are mostly about 4-5 lines in text. Finding the related contents in the book is enough to solve most of the problems. Since the exam time is only 1.5 hour, time constraint is more of a problem.

P.S. The score of each question is not provided in question paper, which may bring some problem to time allocation (to slow students like me)
P.S.2. When the exam begins, the professors verbally announces that the last question is difficult so we may try to complete other questions instead of attempting this question. However, the answer turns out to be similar to Artin's Cor 15.3.8.

Statistics: (Canvas data only)
HW1: score not released as submission is not done by canvas. Me: 75/93 -> ~80%
HW2: Mean: 80.24 High: 98 Low: 56 Me: 88
HW3: Mean: 72.44 High: 95 Low: 37 Me: 79
Final: Mean: 51.74 High: 83 Low: 0 Me:62
Finally A-, seems to be fair enough
reviews.comment_workload:
The proposed syllabus said 6 hws, but it turn out to be 3.
The number of questions in each hw is also decreasing.

HW1: 46 questions + 6 optional in Ch 2, intended to dead on 12 Feb but changed to 27 Feb
HW2: 20 problems in Ch 7
HW3: 13 problems + 3 optional in Ch 11
Self-exercise4: 2+8+9 questions in 3 remaining topics

Professor's comments on exercise 4: As the previous three assignment already include most of the basics that an algebra course requires, and as the topic "Factoring" and later topics "Field and Galois Theory" are advanced ones into PG levels, this last homework will not be graded and no need to be submitted.

The workload keeps decreasing along the progress. It is quite delightful as I think most people enrolled were mentally prepared for huge workload.
Still, a decent amount of time is required to understand the contents well so the workload should be C.

reviews.author: xdlok
reviews.title: Actual Abstract Algebra Course
reviews.comment_content:
Content (not in order):
Basic definitions, First Isomorphism Theorem

Group:
Group of Rigid Motions, Wallpaper Groups (Crystallographic Restriction)
Group Action, Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem, Symmetry of Platonic Solids
Sylow Theorems, Classification of (some) finite groups

(Commutative) Ring:
Ideals
Euclidean Algorithm
Gaussian Integers
Elementary Number Theory(Fermat's Little Theorem, Wilson's Theorem, Euler's Theorem, Chinese Remainder Theorem)
RSA encryption
Prime, Irreducible
Polynomial Rings and Application to Invariant Subspaces
Domains, PID, UFD
Gauss's Lemma

Field, Vector Space:
Introduction

This course makes MATH 3121 looked like MATH -1003 (minus 1003), while 3131 is 1013. There are much more content in 3131. This course should be called Abstract Algebra instead.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His Teaching is kind of dry. He just writes everything on a piece of paper projected through the visualizer, and nobody asks any questions for some reason. But the lessons are not boring at all since everything is (should be) new to everyone. He explains things very clearly so there are usually no need to ask questions. He is very nice though, and he will answer questions after class (assume that you have any)

Professor love not using the standard notation for things. For example, the notation for normal subgroup (the triangle thing), S_n, D_n, A_n, and so on, are NOT used, making self study kind of difficult, especially when the recommended reference, Artin, uses those notation just fine.

The TA usually put up difficult questions and he talks fast. He also introduces tons of new definitions and theorems (maximal ideal, FTFGAG,...) which makes the tutorial even harder to follow. But the questions in the tutorial are quite insightful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good (I guess).
Grading Scheme:
30% Midterm
45% Final
25% Quizzes and Homework

For the Midterm and the first quiz, professor gives a "make-up" midterm/quiz that can be taken home to attempt to replace the original scores. (Of course the cap is much lower, but still)
He predicts our grades after the midterm, and writes down the grade on the final paper (I saw it when I checked the final exam).

Note that professor reveals one question (or a part in the question) for each quiz so you know what to expect.

There are no statistics available except for a horrible midterm score histogram so I don't know how good I am compared to the others (probably not good).
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload can be very high. There is 1 homework each month. If you are a dead line fighter like me that only start to do the homework the week before the deadline, you will suffer for sure. That said, I did that for all 3 homework.

The content in the homework though, is debatable. He puts things that are not taught into the homework, and usually the some topics mentioned in it are not taught until the day before the deadline. WTF? Luckily the TA explains (and basically gives the solution on) some of the harder questions.

The workload is similar to MATH 2043 basically (except compressing 2 homework in 2043 to 1 in 3131)

reviews.comment_content:
He uses the book "Algebra" by Artin, covering chaps 2,10,12,13. I think it's fine and definitely covers all the necessary knowledge in abstract algebra, much more than an introductory course.

I didn't like the book at all. I found it extremely dense. The explanations are not clear and it's quite hard to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Where do i start? No joke, this guy's one of the worst profs i've encountered in UST. I get the feeling that for most of our classes, he starts the classes without any concrete plan of what he's going to talk about, then he just randomly blabbers and sees where his ideas lead him. Most of the time, he just brings up a topic, goes "oh this idea is interesting", then he laughs to himself and moves on without even explaining much.

Then he would open a pdf of the book to see "what he missed" (spoiler alert: a whole lot of stuff, since he basically just skims through everything), then he would go and hover his mouse over some text while talking in a monotonous voice for 20 minutes. not exactly the most engaging way to learn.

There were times when he would say "oh this thing is important you can read it yourself in the book". Man, if it's important you should really be teaching it instead of telling us to read it ourselves. He would sometimes also say that if a proof if "more than 5 lines", then it's too long to discuss in class and that we should read it ourselves.

It's also not uncommon for him to finish blabbering around 30 minutes early, then he just goes and asks us if we have any questions. seriously? you barely discussed anything, and now class is done? "Funny thing is, that when we did ask question about the homework, it would be as if he had never seen the question before (I think he had not), and there are times where he spend 20 minutes thinking about the question to no avail (then ask us to go home and think about it)." (quote from MATH 5111 review. go check it out. I agree with the points.)

tldr: this is basically a self-learning course. which is extremely difficult if the book he uses is also not great.
reviews.comment_grading: Seems ok. Though we never got much feedback from our hw, which I think is a terrible practice since we never find out where we went wrong.
reviews.comment_workload:
In the first meeting he basically said, "answer all even numbers in the book". I'm fine with using book questions as HW, but honestly saying "all even numbers" just seems the prof saying "i'm too lazy to even pick out which problems are appropriate for the class, so let's just answer half of the questions!"

"All even numbers" amounts to around 40 questions every 2 weeks, ranging from quite simple to really hard.

reviews.author: UnconMarketeers
reviews.title: A course for pursuing mathematical maturity
reviews.comment_content:
The main textbook is Dummit and Foote. It is a standard textbook with various concrete rigorous examples.  In previous years, it seems that most of the professors use Artin's book. However I don't like it because of the style of storytelling and the examples inside.

Other recommended material is Ivan Ip's MATH5111 notes. It is basically this years MATH3131, plus category theory, field theory and Galois theory, so Ivan's note is a good summary on MATH3131 basically.

Prerequisite: It seems that (theoretically) there are not many strict prerequistes for learning abstract algebra. However, I recommend future students having some background knowledge to the following:

1. Discrete mathematics. In fact one purpose of group and ring theory is to solve number theory and combinatorial problems. In previous year of COMP2711H, there is content related to group, ring and field theory.
2. Linear algebra. The module theory is basically a generalization of linear algebra.

The course is divided as follows:

1. Group theory

-> Definition of groups
-> Discussion of symmetric group
-> Homomorphism and isomorphism
-> Group action
-> Subgroup, Lagrange theorem
-> Coset and quotient group
-> Isomorphism theorems
-> Caylet theorem, Sylow theorem, classification of abelian group...

2. Ring theory

-> Definition of rings
-> Advanced definitions: Integral domain, field, polynomial ring, ideals, PID, ED, UFD, Noetherian ring...
-> Chinese remainder theorem in terms of ideal

3. Module theory

-> Definition of module
-> Direct sum
-> Free module
-> Construction of tensor product
-> Exact sequence
-> Vector space and linear algebra over field
-> Tensor algebra, symmetric algebra, exterior algebra
reviews.comment_teaching:
Some good points:

1. Sophisticated: The instructor is an expert on algebra, so he is able to teach with very fast pace and keep a rigorous treatment of the content. As an expert of Lie group theory, he sometimes tells the relation between measure theory/ real analysis and abstract algebra. As an analysis student, I'm quite enjoyable with such linkage between analysis and other topics.

2. (For tutorial) The tutor makes high quality questions for tutorial. If the difficulty of exams is "easy to moderate", the homework questions are "moderate to difficult", then I will describe the tutorial problems as "moderate to extremely difficult". The tutorial of this course has successfully done what it should give to the students.

Room for improvement:

1. The instructor always come to the class late. Usually he is late for around 5 minutes. An extreme case is that in the last lecture he come to the class late for almost 45 minutes... So I cannot give it an A for the teaching part.

2. Sometimes he made minor mistakes, like writing the derivative of x^5 to be 4x^4 (in the first lecture).

Remark: The TA is super effective. After I finished the exam and get back home around 1.5 hours later, I received my final exam score. It's somewhat terrible.
reviews.comment_grading: 30% homework, 20% midterm, 50% final. My personal thought is that, for all abstract algebra courses homework should have highest weight, so I think 50% homework would be better. But given that it is an honors course, the final grading should in overall be not bad.
reviews.comment_workload: 7 homework thorough the course. The difficulty and amount of homework seems to be much higher than MATH3121. The homework problems range from true/false questions to PhD qualify exam questions.
